name: The Carter Center
mission: It seeks to prevent and resolve conflicts, enhance freedom and democracy, and improve health.
theoryOfChange: The Carter Center has a published 'Peace Programs Strategic Plan' (2022) that outlines its vision for a more peaceful, inclusive, participatory, empowered, equitable, transparent, and accountable world. This five-year plan details how the Center will prevent or mitigate the impact of war and conflict and promote democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. It describes new programming tools and approaches, including enhanced collaboration with local stakeholders, extensive integration and purposeful coordination across program areas, an analytical approach incorporating cross-cutting themes, and a country assessment process. The plan explicitly states a commitment to systematically track activities, outputs, and outcomes by growing its monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) resources and capabilities, creating MEL minimum standards, seeking technological solutions for global MEL tracking, enhancing internal MEL capabilities, and regularly using data and evaluation for program tracking and design.
zakatClaimEvidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly)

alignment.rationale: Alignment 29/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: Evaluation source domain 'charitywatch.org' is not a known trusted evaluator

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: The Carter Center Inc earns 62/100 due to strong impact and good alignment (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly)

all_citations.claim: The Carter Center Inc focuses on conflict resolution, democracy, and health programs while maintaining significant working capital.
The organization accepts general charitable donations (sadaqah) to support its global humanitarian missions.
The organization reported total revenue of $153,773,756, a program expense ratio of 81.4%, and fundraising efficiency of $0.08 per $1 raised.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its high financial efficiency and humanitarian urgency, though it lacks specific features tailored for Muslim donor alignment.
areas_for_improvement: Limited specific alignment with traditional Muslim donor preferences or specialized giving frameworks
Data confidence is currently at a medium level, suggesting room for more granular impact reporting

dimension_explanations.alignment: The charity is categorized as sadaqah-eligible, serving urgent humanitarian needs in conflict resolution and health [2]. While it has a strong track record in the humanitarian sector, its alignment for Muslim donors is considered medium as it does not offer specialized pathways for faith-based giving [2][3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high operational effectiveness by allocating 81.4% of its $153,773,756 revenue directly to its programs [3]. With a cost per beneficiary of approximately 0.12 and 91.0 months of working capital, it maintains a high capacity for long-term project sustainability and capacity building [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Carter Center Inc works globally to resolve conflicts, bolster democratic institutions, and improve public health through direct intervention and capacity building.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 81.4%, ensuring the majority of funds reach field operations
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.08 per $1 raised
Robust financial stability with 91.0 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: Founded on the principle of advancing human rights, The Carter Center Inc operates specialized initiatives including the Conflict Resolution Program and the Democracy Program to enhance freedom and stability [1][3]. The organization reported a total revenue of $153,773,756, maintaining a strong focus on international humanitarian aid and disease eradication [3].

all_citations.quote: The Carter Center seeks to prevent and resolve conflicts, enhance freedom and democracy, and improve health.
Your gift helps The Carter Center advance peace and health.

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its high financial efficiency and humanitarian urgency, though it lacks specific features tailored for Muslim donor alignment.

areas_for_improvement.context: While stability is a strength, the current <cite id="1">91.0 months of working capital</cite> is far beyond the industry standard of 1-3 months, suggesting funds could be deployed more rapidly.

Despite clear internal goals, the organization's <cite id="1">evidence and outcomes remain unverified</cite> by third-party evaluators, limiting the ability to independently validate cost-effectiveness.

bbb_assessment.summary: The Carter Center has a BBB review profile but does not currently show as meeting all 20 standards.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's long-term disease eradication goals require significant financial reserves to ensure programs are not interrupted by funding cycles.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">Working capital exceeds 7 years</cite> of operating expenses
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="1">excessive accumulation of net assets</cite> relative to annual spending, which may signal a lower urgency in fund deployment.

data_gaps: Not fully rated by Charity Navigator
confidence.notes: Financial transparency is high, but impact verification is limited.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is moderate as the Center serves <cite id="1">international humanitarian needs</cite> and travelers (ibn sabil), though it lacks specific Islamic framework integration.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be strengthened by <cite id="1">developing specific programs</cite> that address the unique needs of underserved Muslim communities in its conflict resolution work.

credibility.explanation: The Center is highly credible due to its <cite id="1">44-year track record</cite> and leadership by a former U.S. President. It maintains <cite id="3">audited financial statements</cite> and a highly <cite id="1">independent board of directors</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To improve credibility further, the organization should <cite id="1">seek external third-party evaluations</cite> to verify its reported impact metrics.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="3">81.4% program expense ratio</cite> and a delivery model focused on <cite id="1">capacity building</cite>. The cost per beneficiary is estimated at an <cite id="1">exceptional $0.12</cite> for certain health interventions.
impact.improvement: The Center could improve its impact score by <cite id="1">reducing its working capital reserves</cite> to the 1-3 month range and deploying those funds into active programs.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Internal outcome tracking with clear Theory of Change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Funds local partners to implement democracy and health initiatives.

rich_narrative.headline: The Carter Center Inc works globally to resolve conflicts, bolster democratic institutions, and improve public health through direct intervention and capacity building.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value institutional stability and want to support long-term, large-scale global health and peace initiatives through an established American institution.
donor_motivations: Want to support the eradication of specific diseases like Guinea worm
Value high-level diplomatic approaches to conflict resolution
Prefer organizations with massive financial reserves and long-term viability
Seek to support secular humanitarian work that benefits Muslim-majority regions
giving_considerations: Donations are pooled into a very large endowment-style asset base
Focus is on systemic change and capacity building rather than emergency relief
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those who prefer lean organizations with minimal cash reserves.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: While the Center tracks internal metrics like disease prevalence, it lacks rigorous, independent third-party impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The Center uses a model of high-level mediation for peace and community-based volunteer networks for health to create sustainable, systemic change.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Independent evidence ensures that the $0.12 per beneficiary claim translates into long-term health improvements.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With over $1.1 billion in net assets, the organization has significant internal funding, though new initiatives require fresh capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: The Center's <cite id="1">91.0 months of working capital</cite> is significantly higher than the <cite id="1">peer median</cite>, offering unique long-term stability.

strengths.detail: The organization spends only <cite id="1">$0.08 to raise every $1</cite> in charitable contributions, significantly outperforming industry benchmarks for humanitarian organizations.
The Center maintains <cite id="1">91.0 months of working capital</cite>, providing an extraordinary level of long-term sustainability for its multi-year health eradication initiatives.
With <cite id="3">81.4% of total expenses</cite> dedicated to its core programs, the Center maximizes the impact of donor contributions on the ground.

strengths_deep_dive: The Carter Center's operational model is distinguished by its ability to leverage high-level diplomacy alongside grassroots health interventions. Its <cite id="1">Guinea Worm Eradication Program</cite> has reduced cases globally by more than 99.9%, showcasing a rare level of measurable success in public health. This is supported by a <cite id="3">net asset base of over $1.1 billion</cite>, which provides the financial security necessary to commit to decades-long disease elimination goals. Furthermore, the organization's governance is robust, overseen by an <cite id="1">independent board of 43 members</cite>, ensuring diverse oversight and strategic depth.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 1982 by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter and Rosalynn Carter, The Carter Center Inc is a major international NGO dedicated to <cite id="1">preventing and resolving conflicts</cite> and <cite id="1">improving global health</cite>. The organization operates with a massive scale, reporting <cite id="3">total revenue of $153,773,756</cite> in the 2023 tax year. Its work is bifurcated into two primary pillars: Peace Programs and Health Programs. The Peace Programs include the <cite id="1">Conflict Resolution Program and Democracy Program</cite>, which bolster democratic institutions and monitor elections worldwide. Simultaneously, its Health Programs lead international efforts to <cite id="1">eradicate Guinea worm disease</cite> and eliminate other neglected tropical diseases like river blindness. Financially, the Center demonstrates high efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 81.4%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of its resources are directed toward field operations rather than administration. With a <cite id="3">3-year revenue CAGR of 11.9%</cite>, the organization shows steady growth and a robust capacity to manage large-scale humanitarian interventions across more than 80 countries.
